title: Small tweaks to the README
body:
1/ Consistently using "GraphQL.js" rather than "graphql-js"
2/ Kinda crazy but for the longest time I had been mistakenly thinking that you had to navigate to `/graphql/graphiql` to get to GraphiQL by default. Nope, it displays whenever text/html is accepted. BUT - that works anyway accidentally because it's mounted as middleware rather than an endpoint. Anyway I just removed the phrasing that alluded to this past confusion of mine.

title: Context defaulting to request
body:
This PR slightly tweaks the default behavior so that by default the express request is passed as the context object, and updates a decent amount of the README documentation.

The rationale is to make it simpler to support express middleware, in particular authentication. Most express middleware works similarly - some extra field is tacked onto `request`. This is convenient for express developers because the `request` object is accessible from every route handler. The graphql equivalent of a route handler is a resolver, so if the `request` object is simply available to every resolver, express middleware is generally usable without having to alter the graphqlHTTP route handler itself. I think this is an "expressy" thing to do, even if it does not quite aesthetically jive with the deep love of immutability reflected in graphql itself.

Middleware that behaves this way & can now be used without altering the graphqlHTTP method call:
* express-session tacks on request.session
* express-jwt tacks on request.user
* passport tacks on request.user
* multer tacks on request.file or request.files

Note the "advanced scenario" docs of authentication are simpler now - you do not have to pass a function to the graphqlHTTP method, you can just use the same call that was in the "intro".

This is backward compatible unless you wrote code that relies on having a falsy context which seems unlikely.

Documentation changes are mostly self-explanatory. The change to using port 4000 in the example is so that it doesn't conflict by default with create-react-app - a small tweak but this may avoid little bits of confusion. Using 'require' instead of 'import' is a bit sad but preferable for now because it means that this code works with node out of the box - most node developers are not transpiling.

title: Custom http status code response
body:
We are used to return different status codes depending on the error, e.g. 401, 404, 500, etc.
Is it recommended to do this in GraphQL? If so, how to do that in `express-graphql`? 

Thanks.

title: Support for an array of queries in a single request?
body:
What are your thoughts on adding support for multiple queries in a single http request? This is currently possible via additional express middle ware. Does this sound like something that would make sense as a first class feature in express-graphql?

This can be useful when using a per-request query batching tool like DataLoader.

title: Force client to use UTF-8 encoding by setting encoding in Content-Typâ€¦
body: Force client to use UTF-8 encoding by setting encoding in Content-Type header.

title: application/graphql requests being incorrectly handled?
Flow Definitions Removed During Compile/Build
body:
I'm using Flow in my project & I'd like to use all the flow definitions from express-graphql, yet they are removed during the build script.

Disclaimer: I'm unfamiliar with how Travis CI works.

I know I can manually download the project to get access to the 'src' directory where the definitions are, but that seems a bit weird. I'd like to use npm install to maintain all my packages + preserve the flow type definitions.

What is the best practice for preserving flow definitions using npm install? & is there a way to do so that is not package specific & would apply to all flow typed libraries?

title: Add middleware to transform req.query
Return main promise
body: Returning the main promise will let us do things like time execution and perform some cleanups after the request is processed.

title: `rootValue` no longer being passed
body:
After upgrading to latest React NPM packages, `rootValue` it's no longer being passed:

+    "express-graphql": "^0.5.3",
+    "graphql": "^0.6.0",
+    "graphql-relay": "^0.4.2",
+    "react-relay": "^0.9.0",
+    "babel-relay-plugin": "^0.9.0",

title: broken import for typescript
use res.send directly to send data
Remove http-errors from devDependencies
body: http-errors is already a dependency in package.json

title: Close #92, avoid module.exports breaking change
body:
We should avoid breaking change introduced by babel6. This add 

```js
module.exports = exports['default'];
```

to the compiled files.

title: 0.5.2 changes module.export
body:
The symbol exported when using commonjs style require has changed.

In 0.5.1:

```
> require('express-graphql')
[Function: graphqlHTTP]
```

In 0.5.2:

```
> require('express-graphql')
{ default: [Function: graphqlHTTP] }
```

Something related to how es modules are transpiled to commonjs I guess.

title: How to put the request body into context?
Upgrade graphql peer dependency to ^0.6.0
body: Please upgrade.

title: GraphQL Mutation returns 404 outside of graphiql. May have to do with express-graphql
body: I recently worked on a mutation, tested it out in graphiql and it checked out. However when attempting to hook it up the a frontend application it fails. I made a [SoF](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37278775/graphql-mutation-works-in-graphiql-fails-in-application) post about this, not sure if it is express-graphql. The error at hand is that on this particular mutation for some reason the response payload is "Cannot POST /" along with a 404 code. If you happen to know what may be causing this please comment.

title: Content length or transfer encoding response headers
body:
I'm running GraphQL on a few virtual machines within Amazon's EC2 service. These virtual machines are accessed via a load balancer. The load balancer performs some health checks to ensure that the virtual machines are healthy. One of the possible health checks is an HTTP "ping" which simply makes a GET request to a specified path and for the response to be considered healthy it has to respond with a 200 code and either a content length header set, or a transfer encoding header set to chunked.

Right now, GraphQL sets neither. I'd imagine the content length would be the one that makes sense for express-graphql, since it doesn't look like it uses chunking(?).

Do you think we could set the content length header in the response? Or do is there a way to add a middleware after graphql's that calculates that and sets the header?

title: Add documentation for new features
body: This adds documentation for all my PRs: #82, #83, #84, and #85. Maybe the maintainers would prefer to write the documentation instead?

title: Add some meta to GraphiQL HTML
body: Duplicate of #73. Having a `<title>` is nice for DX.

title: Send response to thunk with request
body: I use [`on-finished`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/on-finished) to do cleanup at the end of a GraphQL request. Having the response object is necessary for this.

title: Connect support
body: General node `http` compatibility tested by `connect` support. I could also add a `./koa.js` and `./hapi.js` file at the root of this project to support those frameworks.

title: Update eslint config
body: I was having some troubles with developer tools because eslint was outdated, so this was a prerequisite for development. Maybe duplicate of #79/#80. This PR really isn't required for what I want to accomplish, but helpful for people looking to hack on the codebase.

title: Update GraphiQL version to 7.1
body: The GraphiQL Document Explorer in 7.0 has an issue with attempting to view the details of an Interface type, the issue is resolved in 7.1.

title: Make dependencies up-to-date, needed to fix bug: https://phabricator.babeljs.io/T2212
body:
So, I ran into an issue with the dist/index.js file. I was trying to consume this project as a dependency in a typescript project.  Apparently the older version of babel was incorrectly inserting

```
module.exports = exports["default"]
```

into the compiled code, which was causing this issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/5565

title: Run tests for node v5 and v6 on travis
Implementation of features from #75
body:
This PR contains a couple of new features (because it is easier to open one PR instead of a bunch of PRs with dependencies on one another). This contains an implementation of features from #75 and the small GraphiQL changes I made in #73.

A full list of changes is as follows:

- Updating of the eslint config (using the config from [graphql/graphql-js](https://github/graphql/graphql-js) as I assume they are one in the same).
- Support for any node server framework which supports connect style middleware.
- Feature for production servers which disallows clients sending `query` parameters instead using `operationName` and a predefined GraphQL document.
- Documentation for these features.

With these changes `express-graphql` will no longer only support `express`, so it would be nice to see the project renamed to `graphql-http` representing its polymorphism over HTTP server frameworks. If desired I can also create `./hapi.js` and `./koa.js` files for interoperability with these frameworks.

GraphQL is awesome, let's give it awesome server tooling ðŸ‘
